The Proposal  The  proposal  comprises  (i)  a  program  cluster  approach  for  the 
Second Financial Sector Program Cluster (FSP II) comprising four
subprograms  for  an  aggregate  amount  not  exceeding 
$40 million equivalent; (ii) a program loan of $10 million equivalent 
for subprogram 1, and (iii) a technical assistance (TA) grant for $1.7 
million. The four subprograms will be implemented back-to-back with 
each  succeeding  subprogram  to  be  processed  sequentially  upon 
completion of the preceding subprogram.  
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Finance 
Subsector: Finance sector development 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth; governance 
Subthemes: Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets;
financial and economic governance

The Program   Since  1999,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been 
Rationale   supporting the Government in its efforts to develop the financial 
sector including the formulation of the Financial Sector Development 
Blueprint (2001–2010). The Government adopted the blueprint in 
August 2001, and implementation began in earnest with the first 
Financial Sector Program (FSP I) and associated TA. As a result of 
FSP  I,  the  Government  was  able  to  establish  the  legal  and 
regulatory foundations necessary for a sound and market-oriented 
financial sector; and take strong measures to consolidate banking 
and  introduce  more  stringent  requirements  for  capital  adequacy, 
governance, and risk management. Despite the progress, a number 
of negative factors inherited from the turbulent past persist. The 
formal financial system needs to be developed to be more efficient 
and accessible to ordinary citizens.  
 
With a rapidly growing commercial economy that requires a sound 
financial  system  to  sustain  the  rate  of  growth,  the  Government 
needs  to  develop  the  financial  sector  by  mobilizing  financial 
resources,  channeling  them  to  productive  investments,  and 
managing the inherent risks, if it is to achieve long-term sustainable 
economic growth and poverty reduction. The Asian financial crisis 
provided many examples of the devastating impact that financial 
crises can have on countries, wiping out several years of growth 
within a very short time. Thus to promote economic growth, reduce

ii   
 
poverty,  and  help  countries  avoid  financial  crises,  ADB  has  an 
important role in supporting financial sector development in its client 
countries.  
 
The program loan cluster will support the Government’s continued 
efforts  to  strengthen  the  financial  sector  by  supporting  a 
combination  of  legal  and  regulatory  reforms,  targeted  capacity 
building, improved disclosure standards and financial transparency, 
and establishment of key financial infrastructure. A sound, efficient, 
and integrated financial system is crucial for achieving broad-based 
sustainable  economic  growth;  it  will  help  reduce  poverty  by 
increasing job opportunities, lowering transaction costs of economic 
activities, and extending the outreach of the formal financial sector 
to poor and rural areas. An efficient financial system will promote 
private sector development and foreign direct investment. A robust 
financial  sector  will  protect  the  economy  from  unfavorable 
exogenous shocks that are becoming more common in increasingly 
global financial markets.  
   
Objective and Scope  FSP II aims to promote the development of a sound, market-based 
financial system to support resource mobilization and sustainable 
economic growth. With a growing, resilient, and efficient financial 
system as the expected outcome, FSP II will focus on the following 
activities: 
(i)  Improve confidence and financial intermediation by upgrading 
the payments, clearance, and settlement system to support 
growing financial services; enhancing market confidence by 
improving public financial disclosure and establishing a credit 
information  bureau;  establishing  a  registry  for  tradable 
government securities to support the interbank market; and 
improving the outreach of microfinance institutions (MFIs) in a 
sustainable manner.  
(ii)  Maintain  stability  in  the  financial  sector  by  revising  and 
updating  the  law  on  banking  and  financial  institutions,  and 
related regulations to support financial activities; strengthening 
prudential  supervision  and  regulations  of  banks  and 
microfinance  institutions;  and  enhancing  the  legal  and 
regulatory foundation by drafting a new law on commercial 
contracts  that  includes  specific  sections  on  agencies  and 
franchising. 
(iii)  Promote  good  governance  by  implementing  international 
initiatives on anti-money laundering and counter-financing of 
terrorism; enhancing corporate governance and transparency 
in  the  insurance  industry;  establishing  commercial  dispute 
resolution  mechanisms;  and  improving  the  capability  and 
increasing the number of qualified national accountants and 
auditors. 
(iv)  Enhance  efficiency  by  computerizing  the  management 
information system of the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC); 
and upgrading the skills and capacity of microfinance agencies 
staff.

iii 
Loan Amount and Terms A  loan  of  $10,000,000  equivalent  will  be  provided  from  ADB’s
  Special Funds resources for subprogram 1. The loan will have a 24-
  year term including a grace period of 8 years, and an interest rate of 
1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum 
thereafter.  
   
Program Period and   The implementation period for subprogram 1 is from September 
Tranching  2006–December 2007. The loan will be released in a single tranche 
upon completion of specific tranche conditions and following loan 
effectiveness. 
   
Executing Agency  NBC will be the Executing Agency, and the Ministry of Economy and 
Finance (MEF) and Ministry of Commerce (MOC) the implementing 
agencies. The Financial Sector Steering Committee, established for 
FSP I, comprising senior officers from MEF, MOC, NBC, and other 
government agencies concerned, will meet as required to review 
progress reports from the technical working group, consider pending 
issues, and propose concrete actions to resolve these issues. A 
senior NBC officer will be appointed as program director to assist 
NBC,  MEF,  and  MOC  in  coordinating  day-to-day  program 
implementation; and will submit quarterly progress reports to ADB 
on program implementation. 
   
Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items  produced  and 
procured in ADB member countries, excluding ineligible items and 
imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  All 
procurement of goods and services produced in, and originating 
from ADB member countries will be made with due consideration to 
economy  and  efficiency,  in  accordance  with  standard  public 
procedures  in  Cambodia  and  normal  private  sector  commercial 
practices acceptable to ADB. In accordance with the provisions of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans (1998), the loan proceeds will be 
disbursed to Cambodia as the Borrower.  
   
Risks and Safeguards  Program implementation could face a number of risks, for which 
mitigation measures have been put in place, as appropriate.  
(i)  Exogenous  shocks.  The  external  environment  may 
deteriorate  if  persistently  high  oil  prices  impede  world 
economic growth and trade, and create unfavorable conditions 
in  world  financial  markets.  External  shocks  would  result  in 
slower growth in Cambodia. To a certain extent, this risk could 
be mitigated by oil extraction from Cambodia’s own petroleum 
deposits.  To  date,  Cambodia  continues  to  show  a  high 
resilience to oil price shocks. Concerns also focus on the high 
growth in credit over the past 2 years. Along with foreign direct 
investment inflows, rapid credit expansion is adding to growth 
in real estate investment because of rising property prices, and 
is  causing  the  assets  of  some  banks  to  be  increasingly 
vulnerable  to  real  estate  risks.  Throughout  FSP  II,  the

iv   
 
Government and ADB will undertake periodic macroeconomic 
reviews to assess potential risks to the financial sector. 
 
(ii)  Unexpected  political  disturbance.  Cambodia  has  been 
enjoying very high political unity and stability for several years. 
However the national election scheduled for July 2008, while it 
may not pose a political risk, could cause material risk in terms 
of  delaying  the  law-making  process  during  the  preelection 
period. Subprogram 1 is designed to ensure that most of the 
legal  drafting  that  closely  involves  midlevel  officials  will  be 
done prior to the general election. Once the Government is 
formed,  hopefully  in  2008,  draft  laws  would  be  ready  for 
submission to the Council of Ministers for discussion.  
 
(iii)  Weak  governance  and  corruption  in  the  sector.  Weak 
governance and incidents of corruption could erode investor 
confidence  and  prevent  the  attainment  of  expected  sector 
outcomes. The Government’s National Strategic Development 
Plan  2006–2010  views  corruption  as  a  threat  to  sustained 
growth and development of the country in general. Backed by 
an  active  development  community,  the  Government  is 
increasingly taking a tougher stance against corruption. The 
general consensus is that good governance and measures to 
address corruption are needed for a successful partnership 
between the Government and the development community. 
This was considered during design of the program cluster, 
which will continue targeted improvements to the institutional 
governance  structure,  accounting  disclosure  standards, 
financial transparency, complementary legislation, regulatory 
updates and enforcement, supervision, and surveillance.  
 
(iv)  Vested  interests  may  slow  reform.  Resistance of vested 
interests to the reforms could delay program implementation or 
weaken its impact. This risk is considered moderate since the 
Government has shown immense commitment by persistently 
pursuing the reform agenda under FSP I and recently adopted 
the  Financial  Sector  Development  Strategy  2006–2015  (an 
updated version of the 2001–2010 blueprint). Institutionalizing 
governance reforms in NBC, MEF, and MOC is likely to be a 
long process and the strategic approach of the program cluster 
is  to  focus  on  supporting  the  Government’s  initiatives  to 
(a)  promote  integrity  in  the  regulation  and  supervision  of 
banks,  insurance  companies,  and  microfinance  institutions, 
(b) promote transparency in the decision-making process and 
ensure  that  information  is  readily  available  to  market 
participants, and (c) strengthen the capacity of the various 
supervisory financial institutions.  
(v)  Weak institutional and human capacity. Some risks may be 
associated with weak institutional and human capacity. The 
same applies to the implementation and enforcement of new

v 
laws  and  regulations.  To  mitigate  those  risks,  training 
programs have been initiated at various training institutions 
established during FSP I. FSP II provides financial support to 
the institutions to help update their curriculum. The attached 
advisory TA will reduce the risks arising from weak capacity, 
especially in the implementation of new concepts. With these 
design  safeguards,  the  integrated  benefits  and  impact  are 
expected to outweigh the costs.  
   
Technical Assistance  ADB will provide TA ($1.7 million) to support NBC, MEF, and MOC 
in  implementing  the  policy  and  institutional  reforms  under 
subprogram 1 and reform triggers for subprogram 2, as well as to 
provide the Government with timely policy advice as needed. The 
TA’s objective is to provide assistance to the Government to find 
practical solutions to address these issues, as well as to deepen the 
Government’s  reform  agenda  in  the  financial  sector.  The  TA  is 
estimated to cost a total of $2.0 million equivalent. ADB will provide 
$750,000 from ADB’s TA funding program. Cofinancing will include 
$500,000 from the e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (funded 
by the Republic of Korea), and $450,000 from the Financial Sector 
Development  Partnership  Fund  (funded  by  the  Government  of 
Luxembourg).  ADB  will  administer  the  co-financing  component. 
NBC,  MEF,  and  MOC  will  provide  the  remaining  $300,000 
equivalent in the form of office space, counterpart staff, and other 
support  facilities.  The  main  TA  activities  include  support  for  (i) 
modernization of the payments, clearance, and settlement system; 
(ii)  implementation  of  the  information  technology  component  to 
computerize  NBC’s  core  functions;  (iii) bank  supervision  and 
surveillance;  (iv)  the  Financial  Intelligence  Unit  for  anti-money 
laundering  surveillance;  (v) supervision  and  regulations  of 
microfinance  institutions;  (vi) establishing  a  national  arbitration 
center; (vii) training under the Center for Bank Studies; and (viii) 
legal and regulatory development. ADB will engage the consultants 
on an individual basis to implement the TA activities, in accordance 
with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time) using the competitive selection method. 
NBC  will  be  the  Executing  Agency,  and  MEF  and  MOC  the 
implementing agencies.

I.  THE PROPOSAL  
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
program cluster to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Second Financial Sector Program Cluster 
(FSP II), comprising four subprograms; and (ii) a proposed loan for subprogram 1. The report 
also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for implementing FSP II, and if the Board 
approves the proposed program cluster and loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me 
by the Board, will approve the TA and administration of the TA cofinancing.1 The program 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT  
2.  Sustained  High  Economic  Growth.  Cambodia’s  economy  continues  to  expand 
strongly. Growth has averaged over 10% per annum since 2004, reaching a record 13.5% in 
2005. Economic growth is expected to moderate to 9.5% in 2007. Key indicators for 2001–2006 
(Table 1) show the strong macroeconomic performance. Strong economic growth has been 
largely driven by continued high exports in garments, rising receipts from tourism, and a 
booming construction sector since 2004. Exports expanded by an estimated 27% in 2006 with 
garment exports growing by 21% (garment exports account for 74% of total merchandise 
exports).  Economic  growth  is  gradually  becoming  broad-based  with  increasing  growth  in 
services and the agriculture sector.

3.  Macroeconomic Conditions. Inflation remains relatively low on a regional comparison, 
anchored by the high degree of dollarization in the economy. At a low of 2.8% in 2006, inflation

billion by June 2007. The ratio of gross international reserves to dollar deposits declined from 
85.7% in 2006 to less than 73.5% in June 2007 indicating that maintaining adequate coverage 
of  rapidly  increasing  dollars  in  the  banking  system  is  challenging.  NBC  is  reliant  on  its 
international reserves to provide dollar liquidity to the financial sector.  
 
4.  Improved Fiscal Management. Fiscal performance continued to improve in 2006 with a 
primary budget surplus of 2.3% in 2006 and is estimated at about 2% in 2007. The overall 
budget, which includes capital expenditures (excluding grants), recorded a financing deficit of 
3% of GDP in 2006 which is expected to remain unchanged in 2007. Domestic budget revenues 
increased significantly over the past 2 years due to improved tax collection. The Government’s 
public financial management reform program, launched in December 2004, has started to yield 
results with an increasing proportion of customs and tax revenues collected through the banking 
system and a growing share of treasury payments to suppliers made by check instead of cash. 
Over the medium term, primary budget surpluses are expected to continue and the overall 
deficit will remain about 3% of GDP. Public external debt as a share of GDP continues to 
decline, falling from 38% in 2004 to 31% in 2006; it remains on a sustainable path.  
 
5.  Continued Reduction in Poverty. Poverty incidence has declined rapidly from about 
47% in 1994 to 35% in 2004. Poverty is expected to continue to fall in 2007 given the recent 
economic expansion. Per capita household consumption has risen 32% in real terms since 
2004 (estimated $500 per capita in 2006).  
 
6.  Strong Financial Sector Growth. Broad money supply remains relatively low (21% of 
nominal GDP), but current growth at 43% indicates increased financial sector deepening. 
Private sector credit expanded at the annual rate of 46% in the first half of 2007 and bank 
deposits mainly in dollars grew by a similar amount. Consequently the loan to deposit ratio has 
been rising and is now at 60%. However, the rapid growth in private sector credit fueled by the 
fast expansion in monetary aggregates during the last 2 years may endanger the immature 
financial sector through substandard credit appraisal and inadequate portfolio management. 
The rapid growth in foreign currency deposits is concentrated in a few banks. Credit, which is 
similarly concentrated, is almost entirely collateralized against the booming real estate market 
and  appears  to  be  financing  real  estate  and  construction  investment.  While  reported 
systemwide nonperforming loans remain below 10%, there are concerns about the quality of 
asset classification. The rapid credit expansion reinforces the critical importance of strong 
banking supervision and enforcement of compliance with prudential regulations with priority 
given to assessing asset quality.  
 
III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Sector Description and Performance  
7.  Institutions. Cambodia’s financial system is undergoing a rebuilding process like most 
other institutions following the political instability and institutional destruction of the late 1970s 
and  early  1980s.  Before  1989,  no  formal  financial  intermediation  was  available  and  the

3           
Cambodian financial system was confined to one institution—People’s Bank of Kampuchea, 
which had the dual role of issuer of national currency (the riel) and national treasurer to finance 
government operations. The treasury role was subsequently transferred to the Ministry of 
Economy  and  Finance  (MEF)  in  1990.  This  was  a  period  of  hyperinflation  and  steep 
devaluation  of  the  riel.  Inflows  of  dollars  following  establishment  of  the  United  Nations 
Transitional Authority in 1991 provided a safer alternative to the riel for cash holdings and 
protection against loss of purchasing power; the dollar has since gained legal tender status in 
Cambodia. In 1996, with the promulgation of the Law on the Organization and Conduct of the 
National Bank of Cambodia, NBC was established as the country’s central bank. In 1999, the 
Government enacted the Law on Banking and Financial Institutions. 
 
8.  Growth and Development. At the end of August 2007, the formal financial system 
comprised NBC, 16 commercial banks, 7 specialized financial institutions, and 2 representative 
offices of foreign-based banks; 17 licensed and 26 registered microfinance institutions (MFIs); 
and 6 insurance companies. Cambodia has yet to establish bond or securities markets. The 
predominantly rural nature of the economy, high transaction costs, inability of the real sector to 
put  together  bankable  projects,  and  low  creditor  confidence  have  been  the  main  factors 
resulting in low formal intermediation and outreach within the sector, slow development in 
nonbank financial institutions, and limited range of products and services offered. The financial 
crisis  in  the  late  1990s,  the  adoption  of  the  Banking  and  Financial  Institutions  Law,  and 
membership in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in 1999 and the World Trade 
Organization in 2003 were among the events that provided a strong impetus for financial sector 
reform. A sector analysis is provided in Appendix 2.  
 
9.  Financial Intermediation. The financial sector has been growing from a very low base 
(key financial data is in Table 2). The broad money (M2) to GDP ratio was around 21% at the 
end of 2006 compared to 13% in 2001. Credit to the private sector increased from 6.0% of GDP 
in 2001 to 12.2% in 2006, and total bank deposits to GDP was 17.9% in 2006 compared to 
10.4% in 2001. Public confidence in the banking system is increasing as depicted by the entry 
of additional foreign banks and annual average growth of total deposits by 30% and assets by 
27% between 2001 and 2006 (private sector credit increased by 52% in 2006). While growth in 
the banking system is facilitating economic development, the fast pace of growth requires strong 
supervision and surveillance to ensure banks are weighing all the risks properly. Lending is 
highly concentrated with the leading five banks accounting for 67% of total lending at the end of 
2006  and  competition  is  slowly  picking  up  with  some  evidence  of  market  segmentation 
emerging. Foreign banks do not face any legal barriers for entering the country, and by the end 
of 2006 eight commercial banks had majority foreign owners.  
 
10.  Insurance.  The  Department  of  Financial  Industry  within  MEF  is  responsible  for 
prudential regulation and supervision of the insurance industry, which consists of one state-
owned and four private nonlife insurance companies, and a reinsurance institution that is 80% 
state-owned. Public confidence in this subsector is influenced by the fact that the supervisory 
and regulatory framework is still under development and by the negative publicity surrounding 
the closure of the insolvent insurance company, Indochine, in 2004. The insurance subsector, 
with a total premium income of only $13 million (0.18% of GDP) in 2006, is still in its early stage 
of development, and the underlying concepts and business transactions peculiar to insurance 
are very new in Cambodia. The main insurance products available locally address liabilities 
arising from construction work, commercial motor vehicles, and public transport third party 
policies. An insurance industry association was established in 2004.

11.  Microfinance. NBC has, since 2003, assumed the role of both licensing authority and 
supervisory authority for microfinance activities. Overall, the microfinance subsector is limited in 
both  relative  and  absolute  size  (total  assets  of  around  1%  of  GDP),  and  is  in  most  part 
dependent on external technical and financial assistance from the international aid community. 
At  the  end  of  2006,  the  total  of  outstanding  loans  of  licensed  and  registered  MFIs  was 
KR374,021.95 million, equivalent to $92.19 million. Voluntary savings of MFIs are very small. 
Licensed MFIs have adopted a wide range of business models, with good corporate governance 
and orderly market development, to deliver their services and products. This was highlighted in 
2006 when Cambodian MFIs won 4 of 20 financial transparency awards presented by the 
Consultative Group to Assist the Poor.

B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Sector Challenges   
12.  Early Stage of Development with Low Investor Confidence. The weaknesses of the 
financial sector stem mainly from the fact that commercial development is still in its infancy. 
Since  1999,  ADB  has  helped  to  implement  reforms  to  establish  the  legal  and  regulatory 
foundation and incorporate strong norms within NBC in terms of how it discharges its prudential 
function. The capital base of the banking system has been strengthened but remains highly 
liquid. Given the high liquidity, to remain profitable banks offer short-term loans (longest duration 
of 3 years) at high interest rates. Competition is still very weak and profitable investment 
alternatives are lacking. Financial outreach is low with limited diversification in products and 
services available to potential customers. The ability of the real sector to maintain and prepare 
reliable financial reports continues to be a challenge. Efforts to develop appropriate accounting 
and reporting standards; strengthen the credit information-sharing system; and modernize the

5           
management information systems of banks (including NBC), and the payments and settlement 
system will boost confidence and financial intermediation in the sector. In particular, early 
standardization of financial sector architecture and the nationwide sharing of common platform 
and  system  applications  are  crucial  for  expanding  the  system  to  accommodate  growing 
demand. 
 
13.  Underdeveloped Commercial and Institutional Framework. Like other developing 
economies, the fundamental weaknesses that stifle financial sector development in Cambodia 
stem mainly from its underdeveloped commercial and institutional framework, low formalized 
enterprise development, and limited human capacity and technical expertise. The court system 
lacks the judicial capacity to enforce contracts and resolve commercial disputes on a consistent 
basis. This contributes to the lack of public and investor confidence in the sector. Enterprises 
that have enjoyed many years of operating without any established rule of law prefer to remain 
informal. The majority of participants in the real sector are reluctant to enter into any form of 
formal financial transactions for fear of being exposed to the tax authorities. Efforts to get the 
National Assembly to adopt the remaining commercial laws and have the Government launch 
an  online  registry  for  secured  transactions,  establish  dispute  resolution  mechanisms,  and 
enhance  institutional  and  technical  capacity  are  beginning  to  succeed  and  when  fully 
implemented will help mitigate these issues.  
 
14.  Shallow  Financial  Sector.  Cambodia’s  financial  sector  has  gone  through  major 
restructuring and reforms since the mid-1990s. For instance, NBC led the relicensing program 
that brought about the closure of 16 nonviable banks in 2002, raised capital requirements for the 
remaining banks to $13 million equivalent, and set the minimum capital adequacy ratio at 15% 
of risk-weighted assets. Privatization of the only state-owned commercial bank (Foreign Trade 
Bank) was completed in 2005. Banks have been free to set their own interest rates since 1995. 
Nevertheless, the financial sector is shallow and dominated by banks. Broad money at 21% of 
GDP is relatively low compared to neighboring countries (Figure 1) indicating that Cambodia 
has  much  work  to  do  to  deepen  its  financial  sector.  The  average  interest  rate  spread  in 
Cambodia has been persistently high compared to neighboring countries, although in recent 
years it declined with increased competition from new banks, in particular with the entry of ANZ 
Royal. Improvements in financial intermediation in Viet Nam, for example, have helped reduce 
interest rate margins and deepen its financial sector. Several factors have contributed to higher 
transaction costs. First, the payments settlement system is underdeveloped lacking an efficient 
and real time electronic settlements system for clearing checks and other transactions. Second, 
until recently, banks have not had a mechanism for sharing credit information to help them 
properly  assess  credit  risk.  Third,  weak  legal  institutions  for  contract  enforcement  and 
bankruptcy increase the risk of lending in Cambodia.  
 
15.  Bank  Supervision  and  Vulnerability  to  Shocks.  The capacity of NBC for off-site 
supervision of banks has been upgraded and strengthened. Regulatory standards have been 
gradually  improved  and  relevant  prudential  regulations  added  to  maintain  NBC’s  primary 
objective of enhancing soundness of the banking system. All banks adopted a uniform chart of 
accounts in 2004 and commenced publishing their annual audited financial reports in 2005. At 
the end of 2006, NBC’s Bank Supervision Department published its second annual report 
providing  a  very  detailed  and  comprehensive  assessment  of  the  banking  system.  These 
developments are evidence that NBC is serious about market transparency and has made 
significant progress to establish a sound regulatory and efficient supervisory regime to enhance 
integrity of the banking system. Although enforcement of prudential regulations is improving, 
compliance with prudential regulations remains patchy. However, NBC aims to bring banks into 
full compliance by the end of 2007, in particular, those of systemic importance.

16.  Rapid Expansion of Lending. The rapid growth in credit over the past 2 years (52% in 
2006 and 46% up to June 2007) is a concern. Along with foreign direct investment inflows, rapid 
credit expansion is adding to growth in real estate and construction investment that has been 
fuelled by rising property prices. No limits are imposed on exposure to individual sectors of the 
economy; and while the garment and tourism industries are growing, they are vulnerable to a 
number of external factors outside of Cambodia’s control. Credit, which is concentrated in a few 
banks, is almost entirely collateralized against the booming real estate market. Some banks’ 
assets are increasingly vulnerable to real estate risks. Reported system-wide nonperforming 
loans remain below 10%, but general concern focuses on the quality of asset classification.  
Recent on-site inspections2 have discovered a number of banks that are not complying with the 
laws and prudential regulations. The rapid credit expansion reinforces the critical importance of 
strong banking supervision and enforcement of compliance with prudential regulations with 
priority given to nonconforming banks. 
 
17.  Limited Public Awareness and Weak Coordination of Insurance. Developments in 
the insurance industry have produced mixed results. Insurance is still a new concept to most 
Cambodians and the industry as a whole has not worked to increase public awareness to any 
great  extent.  Enforcement  of  the  three  products  available  locally  (commercial  vehicles, 
construction  sites,  and  passenger  vehicle  liabilities)  has  been  very  weak  and  coordination 
between the ministries assigned to oversee their implementation (Ministry of Interior, Ministry of 
Land Management, Ministry of Public Works and Transport, and Ministry of Tourism) and MEF 
needs to be improved. The problem of lack of capacity to provide underwriting, actuarial, loss 
adjustors,  fund  management  services,  and  effective  supervision,  remains;  while  current 
accounting practices (statutory or otherwise) are inadequate. A risk-based capital framework is

approach, and legal framework for insurance businesses are important to put the industry on a 
sustainable path and require the continued support of MEF.    
 
18.  Microfinance Constrained by Financial Resources. Banking activities in rural areas, 
although not fully developed, are improving with MFIs providing most of the formal financial 
services (mostly credit). With ADB support, NBC has successfully developed the regulatory 
framework for MFIs, and implemented the licensing and registration process. The microfinance 
subsector is expanding rapidly, with total assets expanding at around 80% in 2006, and the 
assets of a number of individual institutions expanding at 200% annually. Meeting the financial 
resource requirements of this growing subsector from national savings is a challenge, and the 
Government is considering various options. While progress has been positive, a large part of 
the country still does not have access to formal finance. NBC and MEF need to identify the 
areas  requiring  policy  and  regulatory  changes  to  expand  services,  products,  and  savings 
mobilization (directly or indirectly).  
 
19.  Perceived  Corruption.  Like  most  other  developing  economies  where  financial 
resources are scarce and bureaucracy is weak, opportunities for collusion between vested 
interest  groups  for  the  procurement  of  goods  and  services  are  greater  than  in  developed 
countries  with  strong  legal  and  regulatory  regimes.  Cambodia  faces  risks  associated  with 
corruption and vulnerable institutions. Corruption undermines the rule of law and ethics, distorts 
decision-making,  and  deters  investment  and  business  confidence.  Many  of  the  causes  of 
corruption are complex and the Government has been encouraged to strengthen its efforts to 
combat corruption by groups such as the anticorruption informal aid working group representing 
all  multilateral  and  bilateral  agencies  operating  in  the  country.  Cambodia's  membership  in 
regional and international organizations such as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and 
World Trade Organization has increased the momentum of Government implementation of 
anticorruption policies and regulations across all sectors.  
 
2.  Lessons  
20.  ADB  has  supported  reforms  in  the  financial  sector  since  1999,  beginning  with  the 
diagnostic assessment of the financial sector, which resulted in the formulation of the Financial 
Sector Development Blueprint 2001–2010. The blueprint, adopted in August 2001, sets out the 
long-term vision and development strategy for the sector and is in line with the Government’s 
overall  reform  agenda  of  establishing  a  market-oriented  and  private-sector-led  economy. 
Designed within the framework of the blueprint, the loan for the first Financial Sector Program 
(FSP I)3 helped to (i) establish a legal and regulatory foundation for banking, insurance, and 
commercial  development;  (ii)  enhance  public  confidence  and  financial  intermediation  by 
consolidating the banking system, and strengthening supervision and surveillance of financial 
institutions;  (iii)  prepare  the  foundation  for  developing  interbank  and  money  markets;  
(iv)  develop  key  financial  market  infrastructure  (accounting  and  auditing,  credit  information 
sharing system, secured transactions filing registry, etc.); and (v) establish key institutions with 
appropriate capacity support.  
 
21.  The ADB country assistance program evaluation4 found that subprogram 1 of FSP I was 
completed on time and achieved both the outputs and expected outcomes. The evaluation

changes  to  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  institutional  arrangements,

allocated  to  program  implementation.  Design  flexibility  is  also  a  key

understanding, acceptance, and likely adoption of the new measures. Substantial

then consolidated throughout implementation to achieve the intended results.  
 
(iv)  National and Commune Council Elections. Implementation of subprograms 2 
and 3 of FSP I was delayed by elections. The commune and national elections 
affected passage of the draft laws targeted by FSP I through the Council of 
Ministers and National Assembly. This is a lesson for program design as the next 
national general election is scheduled for July 2008.  
 
(v)  Emerging  Risks.  The  transition  from  a  centrally  controlled  to  a  market-led 
economy creates new forms of risks. The presence of international banks, the 
offer of more sophisticated services to depositors, and the increase in lending 
demonstrate  the  increasing  confidence  of  investors  in  Cambodia's  financial 
system. However, with these encouraging developments come new risks and

financial sector must be strengthened and new ways for mitigating risks pursued.  
 
(vi)  Anticorruption  Initiatives.  Previous  decades  of  conflict  and  isolation  have 
resulted  in  weak  governance  and  perceived  high  corruption.  The  speedy 
implementation  of  changes  often  increases  institutional  risks  and  with  it  the 
opportunities for corruption. FSP I reforms were designed to minimize the impact 
of corruption, deter corruption, and to spur the Government to act on cases of 
malfeasance.  
 
3.  The Government Strategy  
22.  Cambodia’s  first  Social  and  Economic  Development  Plan  for  1996–2000  (SEDP  I) 
marked the Government’s first systematic approach to economic growth and poverty reduction 
with the Government closely participating in the development process. The promotion of broad-
based sustainable economic growth as a strategy for poverty reduction continued in the second 
SEDP. Robust growth over the past decade and structural reforms have led to a steady decline 
in the overall incidence of poverty from an estimated 47% in 1994 to 35% in 2004. The gains 
have been widespread, but not uniform, with the incidence of rural poverty remaining high at 
around 39% and income disparity increasing between rural and urban areas. An important 
contributory factor is that economic growth has been narrowly based on clothing and tourism, 
both of which are urban focused with weak linkages to the rural economy. 
 
23.  The  Government  prepared  its  5-year  National  Strategic  Development  Plan  (NSDP) 
2006–2010 in the context of a falling, but still high incidence of overall poverty, and a growing 
rural-urban  divide.  Approved  by  the  National  Assembly  in  May  2006,  the  NSDP  aims  to 
operationalize  the  Government’s  Rectangular  Strategy  (adopted  in  2004)  and  achieve  the 
interim (2010) targets. The Rectangular Strategy sets out the Government’s reform agenda as a 
series of four interlocking rectangles with governance at its core. One of the four strategies 
focuses on the environment required to implement and promote economic growth through 
agriculture,  infrastructure,  private  sector  growth  and  employment,  and  human  resource 
development. 
 
4.  The ADB Strategy  
24.  ADB’s overarching goal in Cambodia is sustainable poverty reduction. In line with the 
priorities and strategies identified in the Government’s Rectangular Strategy (Figure 2), ADB’s 
country strategy and program5 focuses on three strategic pillars: (i) broad-based economic 
growth  through  investments  in  physical  infrastructure,  development  of  the  financial  sector, 
support for greater regional integration, sustainable development of small- and medium-sized 
enterprises,  and  investments  in  agriculture  and  irrigation;  (ii)  inclusive  social  development 
through  basic  education,  empowerment  of  vulnerable  groups  such  as  women  and  ethnic 
minorities, control of communicable diseases, provision of rural water supply sanitation facilities, 
and community-based sustainable management and conservation of natural resources in the 
Tonle  Sap  basin;  and  (iii)  good  governance,  through  improvements  in  public  financial 
management  to  enhance  the  development  effectiveness  of  public  expenditures  and 
decentralization initiatives to strengthen local participation in government and improve public 
service delivery.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
26.  The expected overall impact of FSP II is a sound and market-based financial system that 
enhances  resource  mobilization  and  supports  sustainable  economic  growth.  The  expected 
outcome is a growing, resilient, and efficient financial system. Program formulation considered 
lessons from FSP I and past TAs to the sector.  
 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
27.  FSP  I  successfully  used  the  program  cluster  modality  with  two  tranches  under 
subprograms 1 and 2 and a single tranche under subprogram 3. With ADB’s financial and 
technical assistance, Cambodia has achieved substantial progress in developing the financial 
sector over a relatively short time. In recognition that program-based lending is a changing 
process,  the  development  community  is  promoting  results-based  approaches  with  growing 
focus on understanding the political economy and factors that help shape policy reforms and 
implementation. Interventions are increasingly targeting improved partnerships and increased 
government  ownership  through  the  delegation  of  more  rights  and  obligations  to  recipient 
countries. These innovations allow governments’ greater control over the details of development 
programming  and  policy  implementation;  enhance  ownership  of  the  development  process; 
provide flexibility in resource use; and in principle, ensure greater predictability of aid funds tied 
to a country’s budget cycle.6  
 
28.  Subprograms and Tranching. In view of the national election in July 2008 and recent 
developments in the banking system, FSP II will adopt the program cluster approach. The 
program cluster supports a policy reform program anchored on the FSDS 2006–2015; it was 
prepared by a joint team of Government and ADB representatives. The key features include (i) a 
series  of  four  single-tranche  subprograms,  with  a  well-defined  medium-term  framework 
specified  at  the  outset  and  including  key  reform  actions  to  be  completed  prior  to  Board 
consideration; (ii) triggers7 for subsequent subprograms to ensure continuous dialogue between 
the Government, ADB, and stakeholders; and (iii) a small number of well-targeted policy actions 
designed to achieve high-impact outcomes in priority areas. The four subprograms are to be 
implemented from September 2006 to 2010. Subprogram 1 has 14 key reform actions that the 
Government began implementing in September 2006. All have been completed prior to Board 
circulation. Disbursement will follow after loan effectiveness.  
 
29.  Links  between  Subprograms.  Subprograms  1  and  2  are  linked  by  key  actions 
(triggers) that are deemed essential for the success of the medium-term program. Progress with 
implementation of these key actions will be an indicator of readiness to proceed to the next 
subprogram. Subprogram 2 covers January–December 2008 and assuming good progress with 
implementing the associated triggers and the Government’s readiness to implement successive 
triggers, it is expected to be processed for Board approval and disbursement in December 
2008. Subprogram 3 covers January–December 2009 and will be processed for Board approval 
and disbursement in December 2009 based on the progress achieved in implementing the 
related triggers. Subprogram 4 covers January–December 2010 and will be processed for

1.  Improve Confidence and Financial Intermediation 
a.  1.1 Improve Financial Services and the Payments, Clearance, and     
Settlement System 
31.  A payment, clearance, and settlement system is necessary for resource mobilization and 
service  outreach;  for  development  of  money  and  interbank  markets;  and  to  support 
macroeconomic policy implementation. Improving system will help restore confidence, enhance 
growth in financial intermediation and outreach, and encourage product and service innovation. 
The vast majority of transactions in Cambodia are conducted in cash rather than by check; cash 
transactions are estimated to be mainly in dollars. The high degree of dollarization of the 
economy is understandable given Cambodia’s political history and very high rates of inflation 
during which the dollar proved to be a safeguard against potential losses in purchasing power. 
Credit cards are accepted at only a few establishments and no more than about 50,000 debit 
cards have been issued to date, equivalent to less than 1% of the adult population. The debit 
cards can be used only in the automated teller machines (ATMs) of the issuing bank. 
 
32.  With  the  current  system,  checks  are  manually  cleared  and  settled  through 
clearinghouses operated by NBC (in Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, and Sihanoukville, with no 
electronic  link  between  them).  Checks  are  presented  each  morning  at  9:30  a.m.,  and 
dishonored  checks  flow  back  through  the  system  at  3:00  p.m.  Settlement  from  clearing 
operations is recorded in the NBC books at each branch office. In view of this current archaic 
system, NBC places high priority on upgrading the payment and settlement system because (i) 
the rapidly growing economy is straining the existing manual system; an upgraded system is 
urgently required to support the larger, more complex financial transactions in the economy; and 
(ii) moving from the cash-based to a check-based treasury accounts system would enhance 
public financial management capacities throughout government. To successfully implement the 
payments and settlement system upgrade, NBC has identified the need for a full-time resident 
advisor  to  provide  guidance  and  support  for  the  design  and  implementation  of  a  modern 
payment and settlement system. Subsequent to NBC’s requirements, TA resources have been 
identified under FSP II to assist NBC in this area.

14   
 
33.  The process for modernizing the national payments and settlement system started in 
late 2004 when NBC established the Payments Policy Unit. With the required technical support, 
this unit will play an important role in the future evolution of the payment system. In 2005, 
Cambodia  enacted  the  Law  on  Negotiable  Instruments  and  Payment  Transactions,  which 
provides a legal basis for negotiable instruments such as checks, bills of exchange, promissory 
notes, and regulation of payment systems. Among its top priorities, the Payments Policy Unit 
needs to establish a relationship with all banks operating in Cambodia, to obtain their input on 
unit initiatives. Unit staff has commenced this consultation with banks to garner their support for 
implementation  of  the  proposed  road  map  (Appendix  5)  to  modernize  the  payments  and 
settlement system. Under subprogram 1, NBC has signed a memorandum of understanding 
with each commercial bank endorsing a road map to modernize the payment and settlement 
system. 
 
            b.  1.2 Enhance Consumer Access to Credit and Market Confidence 
34.  The orderly development and expansion of the financial market requires knowledgeable 
customers as well as knowledgeable suppliers. It also requires customers to be able to make 
informed decisions on the services they need and what those services are worth. Since 2005, 
all banks have been required to publish their audited financial statements to allow the general 
public to make informed judgments regarding where to place their deposits and which bank to 
transact with. Several banks have published these annual audited financial reports on their own 
websites, while others provide hard copies that are often out of stock. FSP II will support NBC in 
its efforts to promote bank transparency by requiring all audited financial statements of banks as 
well as prudential regulations to be published on the NBC website. This will help promote 
transparent and positive competition that will encourage public confidence, product and service 
innovation, efficiency, and economies of scale. The recent high credit growth and high growth in 
broad money supply requires close monitoring. NBC will provide periodic macroeconomic data 
for ADB to assess the performance of the financial sector during subprogram 1. 
 
35.  To improve the quality of credit underwriting and portfolio management, and boost the 
confidence  of  the  banking  system,  a  credible  credit  information  system  and  supporting 
regulations are needed. With close cooperation between NBC and the Association of Banks, a 
pilot online credit information sharing system (CIS) was established in August 2006 to support 
the credit appraisal processes of participating banks. The CIS is part of the Government’s initial 
efforts to promote sound credit assessment and risk management within the banking system. 
Rules, regulations, procedures, and a governing structure are in place, but implementation has 
not met expectations. Several banks have not incorporated the need for regular queries to the 
CIS  into  their  internal  credit  appraisal  processes.  Participating  banks  report  that  since 
introduction of the CIS, they have had difficulty getting borrowers’ consent to upload credit 
information  regarding  loans  extended  before  August  2006  (this  is  not  a  problem  for  new 
borrowers since August 2006). Further, the CIS Steering Committee has not enforced its rules 
for reporting. Several additions have been made to the system to allow “no cases to report” as a 
quick option for participating banks, which can then trigger a more focused follow-up by the CIS 
Steering Committee. Mechanisms to assist the reporting requirements of the CIS Steering 
Committee to the CIS Board of Directors are being developed. A number of actions are being 
taken under the Small-and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Program to build steering 
committee capacity to work with the system. The Government will continue to strengthen bank 
compliance  and  intends  to  establish  an  appropriate  minimum  threshold  to  allow  MFIs  to 
participate. Support under subprogram 1 is expected to continue familiarizing all stakeholders 
with the system and help with any important changes to the governing structure of the CIS that

15           
may  be  necessary  for  its  effectiveness.  The  Government  intends  to  move  the  CIS  into  a 
corporation (so that it may function as a credit bureau) with private sector ownership involved.  
 
c.  1.3 Establish a Registry for Tradable Government Securities 
36.  The Law on Government Securities, enacted in January 2007, provides a framework for 
the efficient issuance and management of government securities. This in turn is to ensure that 
the Government’s financing needs and payment obligations are met at the lowest possible cost, 
and will provide key information to financial sector participants through the development of a 
yield curve. NBC has been assigned the role of maintaining the registry function. In preparation 
for the issuance of government securities and as part of the triggers for subprogram 2, NBC will 
establish the registry and train the staff on its operation and procedures. 
 
d.  1.4 Promote Outreach in the Formal Sector  
37.  Cambodia’s  formal  microfinance  industry  has  undergone  a  transition  from  the 
development model to a fully commercial model, although some funding is still channeled from 
aid organizations and their affiliates. In addition, a large number of money changers (who are 
required to be registered), money lenders (who are not required to be registered), about 60 
unrestricted nongovernment organizations, and other participants operate across the country. 
By  some  estimates,  the  informal  sector  has  a  greater  share  by  value  and  number  of 
transactions  undertaken  within  the  economy,  (especially  within  the  poor  and  remote  rural 
population) than the formal sector, which comprises registered banks and both licensed and 
registered MFIs. At present, no reliable data is available on the actual size and scale of the 
informal financial sector.  
 
38.  An understanding of the size and depth of the MFI subsector outside of the formal 
financial sector needs to be established to help determine the needed policy, both macro and 
micro, and amount of assistance needed to develop the subsector. A survey would be useful to 
gather information on nonlicensed MFIs outside the formal sector and their impact on the 
economy. It would include data on size, scale, and scope; and cover both products offered and 
locations  serviced.  Both  NBC  (for  licensing  and  supervision  purposes)  and  MEF  (policy 
formulation) have agreed to jointly undertake this survey as one of the triggers for subprogram 2. 
 
2.  Maintain Stability in the Financial Sector 
a.  2.1 Update the Legal and Regulatory Framework for Banks 
39.  Since  the  adoption  of  the  Law  on  Banking  and  Financial  Institutions  in  1999,  a 
comprehensive review of this law is needed to effectively address the features of a changing 
domestic market and the reality of increasing international economic integration. The review 
should take into consideration consumer protection in connection with the use of debit and 
credit cards, and bank secrecy provisions to support development of the CIS; and procedures 
for administering distressed and insolvent banks, and protection or immunity of bank regulators. 
The revised law is to be submitted to the Council of Ministers and the National Assembly during 
FSP II. NBC will introduce all the appropriate core principles of Basel I (asset grading and 
provisioning,  large  exposures,  and  treatment  of  related  party  transactions)  to  ensure  that 
portfolio data, including nonperforming loans, are properly reported and appropriate actions 
taken  in  a  timely  manner.  Under  subprogram  1,  NBC  has  issued  (i)  regulations  on  large

16   
 
exposures of banks and financial institutions, and (ii) regulations to amend the prakas8 on 
licensing of commercial and specialized banks. 
 
b.  2.2 Strengthen Supervision Capacity for Banks 
40.  Updating and upgrading skills is a priority area that must be an ongoing feature of 
development and deepened in line with the deepening of the financial system. As the number of 
financial institutions increases, new products and services will need to be developed. New risks 
will emerge requiring that skills development and training be pursued in tandem with these 
developments. NBC will continue to strengthen and upgrade the capacity of its own supervision 
staff to be able to effectively manage these developments. At the same time, NBC recognizes 
that the financial sector is still in its early stage of development and thus will strengthen its 
surveillance mechanisms. IMF has been providing a resident adviser to help develop the off-site 
capability of the supervision staff together with an on-site supervision expert to help NBC 
undertake regular on-site examinations of some high-risk banks. IMF has agreed to continue 
this technical support.  
 
41.  NBC has identified the need for ADB support for the on-site supervision of the remaining 
banks. This is very important in view of the rapid increase in the number and size of loans and 
concern  with  the  quality  of  information  reported  by  banks.  NBC  has  formulated  remedial 
measures, broadly anchored on the policy matrix and program policy framework, covering 
stronger sanctions to help it address potential vulnerabilities in the banking system. NBC will 
closely monitor progress with implementation of the remedial measures and ADB will regularly 
review progress reports. Under subprogram 1, NBC has (i) assessed and identified capacity 
building needs for banking supervision, and (ii) strengthened surveillance and has undertaken 
prompt  corrective  measures  for banks  that  are  not  conforming  to  the  laws  and  prudential 
regulations. 
 
c.  2.3 Strengthen Prudential Supervision and Regulations for MFIs 
42.  Financial regulation and supervision are essential to protect against financial crisis not 
only through the protection provided by the regulator but also through incentives and guidance 
given  to  financial  institutions  through  regulations  and  surveillance  to  enhance  their  own 
operations. NBC made very good progress in building the regulatory framework for licensing 
and supervising licensed and registered MFIs. A division for prudential supervision of MFIs, 
established  within  NBC’s  Banking  Supervision  Department,  has  issued  several  prudential 
regulations in the form of prakas. These regulations aim to promote public confidence, support 
best practices and transparency, and prevent fraud and illegal activities. Staff of the division has 
had some training through technical support9 from ADB to undertake off-site and, to a limited 
extent, on-site supervision. Under subprogram 1, NBC has issued regulations to amend the 
prakas on the licensing of microfinance institutions. 
    
d.  2.4 Enhance Legal Foundation to Support Financial and Commercial 
Transactions 
43.  For finance to develop beyond basic, short-term, and mainly cash-based transactions, a 
rule of law system for commerce and finance must be developed, updated, and implemented.

44.  The Government has requested ADB support to complete the drafting of a new law on

3.  Promote Good Governance 
a.  3.1 Promote International Initiatives on Anti-Money Laundering and 
Counter- Financing of Terrorism 
45.  Work to implement an anti-money laundering and counter-financing of terrorism (AML 
and CFT) regime in Cambodia will support international efforts to deter money laundering and 
financing of terrorism activities, and promote standard governance principles. This will help 
restore market confidence and discipline. A pilot Financial Intelligence Unit was established in 
June 2005 with six staff under NBC’s Bank Supervision Department to help with the initial 
preparations.  Throughout  2005  and  2006,  NBC  and  AUSTRAC  conducted  joint  training 
workshops on AML and CFT in general, including procedures to assess suspicious transactions 
reports, the roles of compliance officers at banks and financial institutions, and conducted an 
AML and CFT assessment. Subprogram 1 has supported the Government in its successful 
efforts to adopt the law on AML and CFT. This will be followed by the adoption of subdecrees 
for establishing the Financial Intelligence Unit and coordinating AML and CFT activities in 
subsequent subprograms. 
 
b.  3.2 Enhance Corporate Governance and Transparency in the 
Insurance Industry 
46.  Building  consumer  confidence  in  insurance  as  a  service  will  first  require  public 
understanding of the business of insurance and the services it can provide. Business must be 
conducted as transparently as possible to protect consumers, and ensure that information 
provided to the regulator and the general public is accurate. FSP I helped MEF implement the 
Insurance Law, establish the Insurance Supervisory Unit, provide training support for unit staff,

18   
 
introduce the regulatory framework for new insurance products, and promote restructuring of the 
state-owned insurance firm and involvement of the private sector in the industry. The profile of 
the industry is still low and market size is very small. Under subprogram 1, MEF has issued 
regulations on (i) premium rates for fire insurance, and on (ii) licensing of general and life 
insurance companies. 
 
47.  To enhance the credibility of the insurance industry, the goal for all participants is to 
raise their operations to international standards. Companies with international shareholders 
have introduced these standards to Cambodia. The regulator and the reinsurer are responsible 
for reinforcing these standards. The Government and the insurance association can contribute 
to development of the insurance industry by increasing public awareness about insurance, and 
the regulator could take a leadership role by ensuring transparency within the industry, with the 
general public, and with other government ministries. The trigger for subprogram 2 involves 
support to MEF in preparing and adopting an appropriate reporting standard for insurance 
companies.  
 
c.  3.3 Establish Commercial Dispute Resolution Mechanism 
48.  To promote good governance and boost public confidence in the financial system, the 
Government  enacted  the  Law  on  Commercial  Arbitration  in  2006  and  the  subdecree 
establishing a national arbitration center is scheduled to be adopted in 2007. The arbitration 
center will improve the effectiveness and efficiency of the commercial and financial systems, 
and provide the commercial community with a cost-effective process for dispute resolution 
based on the rule of law. With increased public awareness of the functioning of the arbitration 
center, confidence in the financial sector should increase. However, before the center can 
commence operation, members of the judiciary, legal profession and management personnel 
will need to be trained. FSP II will support MOC’s efforts to establish a national arbitration center 
with the development and adoption of the implementing subdecree, as well as appropriate rules 
and procedures for commercial arbitration by the Council of Ministers. 
 
d.  3.4 Strengthen the Accounting Institutions and Member’s 
Professional Capacity 
49.  For  efficient  financial  intermediation,  financial  market  infrastructure  needs  to  be 
developed,  particularly  accounting  and  auditing  systems,  supporting  legal  framework,  and 
qualified personnel to implement them. Key accounting and auditing initiatives implemented 
under FSP I include the (i) adoption of a law on corporate accounts, their audit, and the 
accounting profession; (ii) establishment of a national accounting council to set and interpret 
standards;  (iii)  introduction  of  requirements  that  international  accounting  standards  and 
international standard on auditing be applied to all companies incorporated in Cambodia; and (iv) 
establishment of an association of accountants and auditors (Kampuchea Institute of Certified 
Public  Accountants  and  Auditors),  its  bylaws,  a  code  of  ethics  that  complies  with  the 
requirements of the International Federation of Accountants, and establishment of committees 
on education and ethics within the association. In 2005 only 10 locally qualified accountants 
were working in the system. 
 
50.  Subsequent updates of FSP I introduced an initiative to improve accounting and auditing 
capacity through a Government-funded scholarship scheme to assist at least 70 candidates per 
year to train toward the qualification needed to become members of the Kampuchea Institute of 
Certified Public Accountants and Auditors. Up to 2005, these scholarships were awarded to 
government civil servants only. A significant number of these students dropped out for various

19           
reasons, including the difficulty of the course, they did not see the advantage of continuing, or 
they changed departments and were too busy. With the very poor results and through policy 
dialogue, this was opened to the general public and selection to be based on merit. This 
commenced in 2006 and the results have greatly improved. Under subprogram 1, MEF has 
issued  regulations  for  the  criteria  that  would  qualify  enterprises  for  external  auditing. 
Subprogram 2 will continue to support this scholarship scheme. 
 
4.  Enhance Efficiency in the Financial Sector 
a.  4.1 Computerize and Integrate Key Operating Functions of NBC  
51.  Central  banks  around  the  world  perform  a  range  of  services  to  assist  the  sound 
functioning of the economies in which they operate. The key functions of central banks in most 
developing countries include (i) operating monetary policy aimed at maintaining price stability, or 
at  least  a  low  rate  of  inflation;  (ii)  monitoring  the  soundness  of  the  banking  system,  and 
providing a clearinghouse and settlement accounts for clearing interbank payments; and (iii) 
acting as a banker for the Government and other financial sector institutions. In Cambodia, 
where the dollar is now the most widely used currency, NBC cannot fully operate monetary 
policy in the conventional sense. It requires an efficient, effective, and reliable information 
system to help NBC’s Management perform the above core functions.  
 
52.  NBC’s current information technology system is not well-integrated across the bank, 
resulting in duplication and inefficiency. NBC would gain considerable benefits, in terms of 
ability to provide a more efficient service to the banking sector, with the implementation of an 
integrated  system  that  initially  links  the  accounting  department  to  the  cash  management 
functions  in  the  issues  department,  the  customer  account  management  in  the  banking 
operations department, and the foreign exchange transactions in the exchange management 
department. Eventually the system should also link the accounting department to the NBC 
branches  to  promote  financial  deepening  and  operating  efficiency.  A  wide  area  network 
infrastructure will be established at NBC to facilitate real-time clearing and settlement operations 
with head offices of all commercial banks in Phnom Penh. Under subprogram 1, NBC has 
reviewed and adopted the information technology architecture model.  
 
53.  Subsequent  subprograms  will  support  NBC  to  develop  its  overall  management 
information system requirements, restructure its chart of accounts, prepare bidding documents 
for its enhanced integrated information technology system, procure software and hardware 
through a competitive bidding process, install the systems, and train the system and user staff. 
Benefit will also be gained by providing improved application software for other parts of the 
bank—departments that do not need to link to the core banking system in real time, such as 
banking supervision, personnel, and economic research and statistics. The total estimated cost 
is $4.6 million (Supplementary Appendix A).  
 
b.  4.2 Upgrade the Capacity of MFI Staff 
54.  Finding  adequately  trained  and  skilled  people  to  meet  the  needs  of  a  growing 
microfinance industry continues to be an ongoing challenge. Growth puts pressure on the 
delivery and customer sides of the business. Capacity building structures are needed within 
MFIs.  The  Center  for  Banking  Studies  will  (in  consultation  with  the  association  of  MFIs) 
undertake a review of its curriculum with the objective of expanding the scope of training to 
include all aspects of MFI business and increase management awareness of liquidity risk,

20   
 
interest rate risk, concentration of credit risk, and foreign exchange risk. These courses will 
target midlevel staff and managers.  
 
C.  Important Features  
55.  FSP II has several distinct features. First, the Government has shown strong ownership 
and commitment in formulating a 10-year rolling financial sector strategy to guide reforms in the 
sector. FSP II was formulated within the FSDS 2006–2015 framework and draws on ADB’s 
experience and lessons from implementing FSP I and related TA projects in the sector.  
 
56.  Second, the Government under FSP II will continue to pursue, as it did under FSP I, 
phased incremental development of markets that deepens the capacity for resource mobilization 
and risk allocation. This is to be carried out in a manner that is relevant to the country’s needs 
and based on realistic standards and expectations. The high level support provided by the 
Financial  Sector  Steering  Committee  (FSSC),  chaired  by  the  NBC  governor,  will  facilitate 
coordination and guide program implementation to achieve the expected outcomes. 
 
57.  Third, interventions will be implemented in a systematic manner to ensure that (i) market 
development parallels institutional and capacity developments, (ii) linkages across subsectors 
are exploited, and (iii) corresponding risks are mitigated. These interventions can continue 
through to subprograms 2, 3, and 4; and will be supported by TA funds to build understanding of 
risks, formulate mitigation measures, and implement key reform activities. 
 
58.  Fourth,  the  FSP  II  cluster  with  four  single-tranche  subprograms  is  an  appropriate 
instrument  for  maintaining  ADB’s  results-oriented  partnership  with  the  Government  in 
developing the financial sector. FSP II provides a set of policy triggers for subprograms 2, 3, 
and 4 that focus on results and outcomes. Since the Government determines the pace at which 
the triggers are to be implemented, this approach encourages government ownership of the 
reform program; flexibility in the implementation agenda; and the opportunity for policy dialogue 
involving the Government, ADB, and other key stakeholders in the event that economic, social, 
and political circumstances change. The Government’s commitment to FSP II is clear from the 
FSP I results and the development policy letter. 
 
D.  Financing Plan 
59.  The program cluster approach involves four back-to-back subprograms for a total that is 
not to exceed $40,000,000 equivalent. The Government has requested a loan of $10,000,000 
equivalent from ADB’s Special Funds resources for subprogram 1. The loan will be disbursed in 
a single tranche upon satisfactory compliance with specific conditions indicated in the policy 
matrix. The loan will have a 24-year term including a grace period of 8 years, and an interest 
rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. Part of the loan 
proceeds will be used to finance the computerization of NBC’s core functions. MEF and NBC 
have agreed to use the Government’s standard operating procedures for procurement and 
funds transfer. The loan amounts for the three subsequent subprograms will be determined for a 
comparable amount and be processed sequentially upon completion of a set of triggers.  
 
60.  The ADB funds are to support the reforms outlined in the development policy letter and 
policy matrix. The loan amount was determined by the strength of the policy package, its 
development impact, the importance of the sector covered, and the development financing 
needs of the Government, as estimated by MEF (Table 3). The Government’s gross and net 
financing needs will be significant if it is to sustain economic growth above 8% over the medium

21           
term and reduce poverty from 35%. The Government aims to increase development and social 
spending  during  2007–2010,  and  as  a  result  envisages  a  targeted  Government  deficit 
(excluding grants) in the range of 3.0%–3.3% of GDP in 2007 and over the next 2 years. 
According to MEF budget reports, the total net financing (primarily external) requirements for 
2008–2009 are estimated at KR1,886 billion, excluding grants ($460 million equivalent). The 
Government’s debt management strategy is to continue with external concessional debt and 
grant financing of its budget. Over the longer term, the Government envisages a reduction in 
external debt as a share of GDP as the economy continues to expand at a rapid pace and in 
anticipation of oil revenues (although these are of uncertain magnitude and timing). Recent debt 
assessments  by  IMF  indicate  that  the  Government’s  debt  stock  and  servicing  costs  are 
sustainable over the medium-term provided macroeconomic performance (high growth and low 
inflation)  continue  and  budget  revenue  growth  remains  on  track.  External  debt  to  GDP  is 
expected to continue its decline from currently 31% in 2007 to 28% by 2008 primarily due to 
economic growth. The current macroeconomic and fiscal environment provides ideal conditions 
for further reforms in the financial sector, among others. The subprogram 1 loan will help close 
the financing gap for 2008–2009 and support the Government’s reforms to the financial sector.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
  1.  Program Management  
61.  NBC will be the Executing Agency, and MEF and MOC the implementing agencies for 
FSP II. The FSSC, established under FSP I, will continue to coordinate program implementation 
among  government  ministries  and  agencies  concerned.  To  ensure  timely  program

government agencies concerned, will meet as required to review progress reports from the 
technical working group and consider pending issues. The FSSC will propose concrete actions 
to resolve those issues. A senior NBC officer will be appointed program director to assist NBC, 
MEF, and MOC in coordinating day-to-day program implementation. The program director will 
be required to submit quarterly progress reports on subprogram implementation, in particular

62.  The implementation period for subprogram 1 is from September 2006 to December 2007. 
The Government has completed all actions for the release of the single tranche. 
 
3.   Procurement and Disbursement  
63.  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange cost (excluding local

66.  A core component of FSP II focuses on promoting good governance, deterring money 
laundering  and  financing  of  terrorism  activities,  and  implementing  measures  that  will  help 
reduce corruption in the overall sector (A Good Governance Framework is in Supplementary 
Appendix B). FSP II includes measures to improve the management information system and 
reporting standards within NBC, banks, and MFIs; promote the transparency of information 
released by banks and MFIs; improve compliance with and usefulness of the credit information-
sharing system; support implementation of AML regulations; and deter activities that could 
support the financing of terrorism. The increasing use of payment instruments other than cash 
will help discourage corruption particularly at central, provincial, and district treasuries. These 
reforms will help keep savers and investors informed, empower civil society to monitor the 
weaknesses  in  these  financial  institutions,  and  deter  those  that  are  vulnerable  to  corrupt 
activities.
