V.   FSP II IMPLEMENTATION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
70.  In response to the Government’s request, ADB has prepared a TA project to support 
NBC, MEF, and MOC in preparing and implementing key policy reforms under subprogram 1 
and reform triggers for subprogram 2, as well as to provide the Government with timely policy 
advice on a demand basis. The objective of the TA is to provide assistance to the Government 
to find practical solutions to address these issues, as well as to deepen the Government’s 
reform  agenda  in  the  financial  sector.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  a  total  of  $2,000,000 
equivalent. Cofinancing includes $750,000 from ADB’s TA funding program, $500,000 from the 
e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (funded by the Republic of Korea), and $450,000 from 
the  Financial  Sector  Development  Partnership  Fund  (funded  by  the  Government  of 
Luxembourg).  ADB  will  administer  the  cofinancing.  NBC,  MEF  and  MOC  will  provide  the 
remaining $300,000 equivalent in the form of office space, counterpart staff, and other support 
facilities. The main activities of the TA will support (i) modernization of the payments, clearance, 
and settlement system (12 person-months); (ii) implementation of the information technology 
component to computerize NBC’s core functions (26.5 person-months); (iii) bank supervision 
and surveillance (4 person-months); (iv) the Financial Intelligence Unit for AML surveillance (3 
person-months);  (v) regulations  and  supervision  of  MFIs  (4  person-months);  (vi)  the 
establishment of the national arbitration center (3 person-months); (vii) training under the Center 
for Banking Studies (3 person-months); (viii) legal and regulatory development (5.5 person-
months); and TA project management (4 person-months). Two national consultants will be 
required: an information technology expert (20 person-months) and a legal expert (4 person-
months).  A  total  of  89  person-months  of  consulting  inputs  are  required  comprising  65 
international and 24 national person-months. Experience in Cambodia has shown that firms, as 
opposed to individual consultants, have been more expensive and have not been successful in 
recruiting the right mix of consultants, especially when the project requires a diverse set of 
expertise. Because of the varying nature of expertise, the consultants will be engaged by ADB 
on an individual basis to implement TA activities in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time), using the competitive selection 
method. The TA purpose, outputs, methodology, implementation arrangements, budget, and 
terms of references are in Appendix 7. NBC will be the Executing Agency, and MEF and MOC 
the implementing agencies. 
 
VI.   PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.   Benefits 
71.  With a rapidly growing commercial economy that requires a sound financial system to 
sustain the growth rate, the Government needs to develop the financial sector by mobilizing 
financial resources, channeling them to productive investments, and managing inherent risks, if 
it  is  to  achieve  long-term  sustainable  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  The  Asian 
financial crisis provided many examples of the devastating impact that financial crises can have 
on countries, wiping out several years of growth within a very short time. Thus to promote 
economic growth, reduce poverty, and help Cambodia avoid financial crises, FSP II will support 
the Government in its development agenda. 
 
72.  The  policies  supported  by  FSP  II  will  help  reduce  information  asymmetry,  improve 
governance, enhance financial stability, and improve efficiency in the financial sector. These 
factors  will  contribute  to  a  more  conducive  environment  for  continued  financial  market 
development. FSP II is expected to boost confidence among market participants and, with 
improvements to the payments, clearance, and settlement system, financial intermediation will

25           
grow resulting in a wider offering of products and services in urban and rural areas. A sound, 
more efficient, and diversified financial sector will support higher investments and productivity in 
the private sector. Together with broader economic reforms in Cambodia, the reforms in the 
financial sector will contribute to higher economic growth. 
 
B.  Social and Environmental Safeguards 
73.  FSP  II  will  not  entail  any  involuntary  resettlement  or  have  a  negative  impact  on 
indigenous people or the environment. It is classified as category C for involuntary resettlement, 
impact on indigenous people, and impact on the environment. FSP II is a general intervention 
aimed at supporting sustainable economic growth and in that respect is expected to have an 
indirect positive effect on poverty reduction (Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy – 
Appendix 8). 
 
C.    Assumptions and Risks 
74.  FSP II assumes political stability in Cambodia and sustained implementation of sound 
macroeconomic policies by the Government. Given Cambodia’s encouraging results in the past 
decade, both these assumptions are valid and defensible. However, implementation of FSP II 
could face a number of risks; for which mitigation measures have been put in place.  
 
(i)  Exogenous shocks. The external environment may deteriorate if persistently 
high oil prices impede world economic growth and trade, and create unfavorable 
conditions in world financial markets. External shocks would result in slower 
growth in Cambodia. To a certain extent, this risk could be mitigated by the 
potential  supply  of  oil  from  Cambodia’s  own  petroleum  deposits.  To  date, 
Cambodia continues to show high resilience to oil price shocks. Concerns also 
focus on the high growth in credit over the past 2 years. Along with foreign direct 
investment inflows, rapid credit expansion is adding to growth in real estate 
investment because of rising property prices, and is causing the assets of some 
banks to be increasingly vulnerable to real estate risks. The Government and 
ADB will undertake periodic macroeconomic reviews to assess potential risks to 
the financial sector during FSP II. 
 
(ii)  Unexpected  political  disturbance.  Cambodia  has  been  enjoying  very  high 
political unity and stability for several years. The national election scheduled for 
July 2008, while it may not pose a political risk, could cause material risk in terms 
of  delaying  the  law-making  process  during  the  preelection  period  when 
government officials are preoccupied with the upcoming elections. In preparation 
for such a scenario, FSP II is designed to ensure that most of the legal drafting 
that closely involves midlevel officials will be completed prior to the general 
election. Once the Government is formed, hopefully in 2008, draft laws would be 
ready for submission to the Council of Ministers for discussion. Sufficient time is 
factored into the program design.  
 
(iii)  Poor  governance  and  corruption  in  the  sector.  Weak  governance  and 
incidents  of  corruption  could  erode  investor  confidence  and  prevent  the 
attainment  of  expected  sector  outcomes.  The  Government’s  NSDP  views 
corruption as a threat to sustained growth and development of the country in 
general. Backed by an active development partner community, the Government 
is increasingly taking a tougher stand against corruption. The general consensus

26   
 
is that good governance and measures to address corruption are needed for a 
successful  partnership  between  the  Government  and  the  development 
community.  These  were  considered  in  the  design  of  FSP  II  with  continued 
targeted  improvements  to  the  institutional  governance  structure,  accounting 
disclosure  standards,  financial  transparency,  complementary  legislation, 
regulatory updates and enforcement, supervision and surveillance, and sector 
efficiency.  
 
(iv)  Vested  interests  may  slow  reform.  Resistance  to  the  reforms  by  vested 
interests could delay program implementation or weaken its impact. This risk is 
considered  moderate  since  the  Government  has  so  far  shown  immense 
commitment by pursuing the reform agenda under FSP I and recently adopted 
the  FSDS  2006–2015  (updated  version  of  the  2001–2010  blueprint). 
Institutionalizing governance reforms in NBC, MEF, and MOC is likely to be a 
long process and the strategic approach of FSP II is to focus on supporting the 
Government’s initiatives to (a) promote integrity in the regulation and supervision 
of  banks,  insurance  companies,  and  MFIs;  (b)  promote  transparency  in  the 
decision-making  process  and  ensure  that  information  is  readily  available  to 
market participants who need to make informed decisions; and (c) strengthen the 
capacity of the various supervisory financial institutions.  
 
(v)   Weak institutional and human capacity. Risks may be associated with weak 
institutional  and  human  capacity,  as  well  as  with  the  implementation  and 
enforcement  of  new  laws  and  regulations.  To  mitigate  those  risks,  training 
programs have been initiated at various training institutions established during 
FSP I. Subprogram 1 will provide financial support to these institutions to help 
update  their  curriculum.  Program  implementation  will  be  supported  by  an 
advisory TA to reduce the downside risks from weak capacity, especially in the 
implementation of new concepts. With these design safeguards, the integrated 
benefits and impact are expected to outweigh the costs.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The development path in the 1990s reflected the period of liberal entry of financial 
institutions at a time when regulation and supervisory capacity were weak. The era was marked 
by  a  rapid  rise  in  the  number  of  joint  ventures,  locally  incorporated  family-owned  banks, 
branches  of  foreign  banks,  and  state-owned  financial  institutions,  which  resulted  in  most 
financial  institutions  being  poorly  managed  and  almost  half  being  considered  technically 
insolvent. Supported by an International Monetary Fund poverty reduction and growth facility 
that was phased out in 2003, the banking system relicensing program (i) introduced a legal 
framework  for  banks  and  financial  institutions;  (ii)  successfully  closed  all  nonviable  banks; 
(iii) relicensed the remaining banks under strengthened National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) 
supervision requirements; and (iv) initiated restructuring and privatization of the major state-
owned foreign trade bank. Cambodia’s financial sector remains shallow and fragile with limited 
financial intermediation and outreach. 
 
2.  At  present  the  formal  financial  system  comprises  NBC,  16  commercial  banks,  7 
specialized  financial  institutions,  and  2  representative  offices  of  foreign-based  banks;  17 
licensed  and  26  registered  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs);  and  6  insurance  companies. 
Cambodia has yet to establish bond or securities markets. The predominantly rural nature of the 
economy, high transaction costs, inability of the real sector to put together bankable projects, 
and low creditor confidence have been the main factors causing the low formal intermediation 
and outreach within the sector, slow development in nonbank financial institutions, and limited 
range of products and services being offered. 
 
3.  The Government’s vision for the financial sector is for a sound, market-based system 
that will enhance resource mobilization, ensure the effective allocation of financial resources, 
and  contribute  to  broad-based  sustainable  economic  growth  as  embodied  in  the  Financial 
Sector Development Strategy (FSDS) 2006–2015. The FSDS recognizes that for equitable 
growth to occur, a diversified, competitive, but prudentially sound financial system would play an 
important  role  in  national  development  by  ensuring  efficient  accumulation  and  effective 
allocation of financial resources. At the same time, expanding finance brings risks, hence when 
pursuing financial development, a focus on prudential risk management, transparency, and 
uniform application of rules and regulations is needed. 
 
4.  Dominated  by  the  banking  system,  the  financial  sector  has  gone  through  major 
restructuring and reforms since the mid-1990s. In 1996, NBC was established as the central 
bank following promulgation of the Law on the Organization and Conduct of the National Bank 
of Cambodia. In 1999, the Government enacted the Law on Banking and Financial Institutions 
enabling NBC to undertake a relicensing program that brought about the closure of 16 nonviable 
banks in 2002, raised capital requirements for the remaining banks to $13 million equivalent, 
and  set  the  minimum  capital  adequacy  requirement  at  15%  of  risk-weighted  assets.  The 
Financial Sector Development Blueprint, formulated and adopted in 2001, provided a clear set 
of  objectives  and  a  sequenced  program  of  reforms  in  the  financial  sector.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been  the  lead  development  partner  in  supporting  the 
Government’s efforts to implement the blueprint to improve financial soundness and efficiency, 
restore confidence, attract a broader base of high quality financial institutions, and broaden the 
sector’s outreach within the blueprint framework. 
 
5.  The  economy  is  largely  cash-based  and  highly  dollarized.  Dollarization  emerged  in 
Cambodia because public confidence in the local currency eroded following a series of shocks 
during the conflict and financial mismanagement prior to 1989. In some instances dollarization

6.  The private sector is characterized by a high degree of informality, and is dominated by 
the informal sector. Enterprises that have enjoyed years of operating without any established 
rule of law prefer to remain informal. The tax regime is still very open to negotiation and the 
majority of participants in the real sector, especially in rural areas, are reluctant to enter into any 
form of formal financial transactions for fear of being exposed to the tax authorities. Private 
enterprises are generally family owned with no separation between management and owners 
who usually do not maintain proper records, including financial reports that can be considered 
reliable.  
 
7.  Banking System. No legal barriers are in place for the entry of foreign banks. At the end 
of 2006, eight commercial banks had majority foreign ownership. The commercial banking 
subsector  now  consists  of  16  commercial  banks,  7  specialized  financial  institutions,  and  
2 representative offices of foreign-based banks. Despite the increase in the number of banks, 
high transaction costs and markups remain but competition is starting to pick up with some 
evidence of market segmentation emerging. With the exception of the Rural Development Bank, 
the banking system is almost entirely owned by the private sector. Most banks have established 
branches in other urban centers and are planning to open additional offices in those areas. Only 
one bank branch is presently able to provide full banking services for every 120,000 citizens, but 
this is clearly insufficient to meet the nation’s needs.  
 
8.  To date most branches are concentrated in large urban centers, but this is expected to 
change. ACLEDA bank, a former MFI, currently has branches in every province and a total of 79 
sites provide banking services. Canadia bank has 11 branches outside Phnom Penh, and three 
other banks have 4 branches outside Phnom Penh including ANZ Royal bank with automated 
teller machines at each of its branches. In 2006, bank staff totaled more than 4,600, with one 
bank (ACLEDA) employing 3,028 and other banks employing between 20 and 250. Technical 
capacity is still weak and most banks provide their own in-house training to complement the 
training programs offered by the association of banks. 
 
9.  Commercial banking is relatively small but growing quickly, with the more aggressive 
and progressive banks attaining a growth rate that averaged 52% credit and 42% deposit 
growth in 2006. The number of commercial bank loans doubled from December 2002 to total 
164,000 at the end of 2006. If these loans were all to individual borrowers then it would be the 
equivalent  of  providing  loans  to  1.2%  of  Cambodia’s  population.  Total  banking  assets 
represented about 29% of the estimated gross domestic product (GDP) in 2006. The banking 
system is fairly concentrated with about three quarters of deposits held by the six largest 
commercial banks, which also account for about two thirds of total loans.   
 
10.  Commercial banks mainly offer simple services to retail and corporate customers in 
urban areas (time and term deposits, savings accounts, basic loans, domestic and cross-border 
wire transfers, foreign exchange, letters of credit, etc.). Specialized banks are not allowed by

law to accept deposits and commercial banks had about 285,000 depositors (more than 2% of 
the total population) at the end of 2006. Most deposit products are short-term in nature and as a 
consequence  loan  terms  are  also  short  (average  3  years)  with  high  interest  rates.  Banks 
continue to rely on physical collateral and personal guarantee as loan security. More advanced 
banking services are being introduced such as electronic banking and private banking. During 
2006 alone, 69 ATMs were introduced, raising the total from 17 to 86. Several banks have 
indicated that they plan to increase this number. 
 
11.  The  noncash  payment  system  is  very  small  and  of  limited  sophistication.  It  is 
predominantly paper-based and manual. NBC runs the clearinghouse, which operates in both 
riels and dollars. The riel clearinghouse has 15 members (NBC, Ministry of Economy and 
Finance [MEF], and 13 banks) and the dollar clearinghouse has 17 members (NBC and 16 
banks).  Average  daily  amounts  that  pass  through  the  clearinghouses  average  about  
$5.5 million, of which riel clearances represent only around 5%. By volume, about 1,100 checks 
are cleared each day, of which around 95% are drawn in dollars. The first clearance is at  
9:30 a.m., with a second clearance at 3:00 p.m. to handle returns. Banks bring their balances to 
the clearinghouse on diskette. Interbank settlement is by check drawn on the banks’ accounts 
with NBC. The enactment of the negotiable instruments and payment transactions law in late 
2005 and the issuance of key regulations in December 2006 provide the legal framework for 
developing the payments system, introducing new negotiable instruments, and promoting the 
development of money and interbank markets. 
 
12.  NBC’s  principal  mission  is  to  formulate  and  implement  monetary  policy  aimed  at 
maintaining price stability and economic development. Its main functions are to (i) act as the 
monetary authority and conduct monetary policy (NBC has actively intervened in the riel foreign 
exchange market to deliver a stable exchange rate and ensure price stability in riel); (ii) act as 
the sole issuer of the national currency (as such NBC has increased the number of currency 
denominations and replaced worn and dirty bank notes); (iii) act as the supervisory authority of 
the  banking  and  financial  system;  (iv)  oversee  the  payments  system  in  Cambodia;  and  
(v) manage the international reserves of the country.    
 
13.  The banking supervision program and standards have greatly improved since 2001 and 
been extended to cover all banks, a move made possible with the addition of skilled staff. 
Prudential supervision was enhanced with the adoption of the uniform chart of accounts by all 
banks in 2004, and the same banks making their annual audited financial statements publicly 
available since 2005. Several banks have published these annual audited financial statements 
on  their  own  websites.  In  2006,  NBC  enhanced  its  regulatory/supervisory  system  by 
implementing  an  off-site  supervision  system known  as  the  Cambodian  Bank  Reporting  for 
Prompt Corrective Action. The system enables staff to perform a regular analysis of off-site 
reports, and identify risks faced by banks and infringements caused by banks; and then for the 
staff concerned to recommend immediate actions to NBC management. The development and 
implementation of the system has been supported by a resident advisor from the International 
Monetary Fund. NBC continues to undertake on-site inspection of each bank once a year. 
 
14.  Banking, along with other financial and commercial subsectors, continues to face high 
transaction costs attributable to the lack of mechanisms to enforce contracts and absence of 
reliable information. The establishment of the credit information sharing system in 2006 should 
improve the situation, but some time will be required to build a sufficient database. Dispute 
settlement remains a major issue and if unresolved will continue to affect the degree of certainty 
associated with financial and commercial transactions. Financial sector stakeholders would 
undoubtedly welcome the operations of a commercial court and commercial arbitration center to

provide a greater degree of certainty. 
 
15.  Microfinance  Subsector.  Microfinance  is  growing  rapidly  with  assets  expanding  at 
around 80% in 2006, with some institutions expanding at 200% per annum. The expansion is 
allowing microfinance to support and grow the economy, especially in its target market of the 
poor and remote rural population. The microfinance subsector now comprises 17 licensed MFIs, 
26 registered rural credit operations, and around 60 nongovernment organizations operating 
unrestricted  across  the  whole  country.  Registration  and  licensing  commenced  in  2002.  A 
number have transitioned from aid-focused nongovernment organizations to commercial MFIs; 
and some were set up as commercial, profit-oriented MFIs from the outset. Most MFIs have 
plans to continue rapid expansion with the establishment of additional branches and increased 
lending activities at existing branches. 
 
16.  MFIs currently have around 400,000 clients (about 2.9% of the total population) with 
loans outstanding ranging in size from less than $75 to a maximum of $5,000, but this can go as 
high as $10,000. The expansion in net number of loans is currently around 10% per annum. 
Voluntary  savings  of  MFIs  are  very  small.  Licensed  MFIs  have  adopted  a  wide  range  of 
business models with good corporate governance and orderly market development to deliver 
their services and products. This was highlighted in 2006 when Cambodian MFIs won 4 of 20 
financial transparency awards presented by the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor. The 
estimate in the 1998 Cambodian census was that 1,750,930 families in Cambodia were poor. 
While huge progress has been made with poverty reduction; an enormous portion of the poor 
and remote rural population still does not have access to effective financial services.   
 
17.  MFIs,  while  growing  rapidly,  have  major  challenges  to  expanding  their  services. 
Addressing these issues should assist them to continue to grow in a sound manner. MFIs face 
competition from informal operators in their markets. The scale of this competition is anecdotally 
said to exceed the size of the formal financial sector but no reliable data is available to support 
this view. A number of costs and challenges are imposed on the industry such as nonresident 
withholding tax, lack of a reliable method to track the use of certificates of title for collateral 
between institutions, and extremely limited access to domestic funding sources. Growth brings 
its own challenges, such as whether management is able to maintain control over business 
processes when the scale of operations begins to outstrip the capabilities of current systems 
and  processes.  Foreign  borrowing  does  bring  growth  and  benefits  in  terms  of  improved 
governance and transparency, but at the same time foreign borrowing brings growing foreign 
exchange risk as institutions increase their lending in the riel-based rural areas. 
 
18.  Money Changers. In addition to banks, the Law on Foreign Exchange (1997) allows 
individuals and legal entities to undertake foreign exchange transactions if they register with 
NBC. They are not allowed to undertake any other financial activity. In December 2006, the 
country had 647 registered money changers; 53 in Phnom Penh and 594 in the provinces. 
Statistics on the transactions undertaken by money changers are not available. 
 
19.  Insurance Subsector. The Department of Financial Industry within MEF is responsible 
for prudential regulation and supervision of the insurance industry, which consists of one state-
owned and four private nonlife insurance companies, and a reinsurance institution that is 80% 
state-owned. The insurance industry is young and small. It has gone through a turbulent period 
but with the introduction of regulations and the enforcement of those regulations, stability and 
growth has returned. The regulator requires the capital of each company to be distributed as 
follows: 10% deposited with NBC, 50% deposited in commercial banks, with the decision on

how to invest the 40% balance left to the insurance company concerned. Insurance companies 
have indicated that they would like these ratios to be changed, and the 40% increased. 
 
20.  Growth has been steady (averaging 11%–13% in the last 3 years) from a limited range 
of insurance products; the total gross premiums were $12.5 million at the end of 2006. The 
three nonlife categories of insurance products (commercial vehicles, construction sites, and 
passenger vehicle liabilities) underwritten in this market are compulsory by regulation. Growth 
has been steady since 2003 with commercial fire and miscellaneous policies making up 47% of 
the market, and motor vehicle insurance 19%. Other products sold include hospital and surgical, 
personal  and  accident,  marine  cargo,  and  travelers  insurance.  The  insurance  companies 
operating in Cambodia are conservatively managed.   
 
21.  The insurance industry requires a number of specialist skills that are not required in 
other industries. As insurance is a fairly new concept in Cambodia, these specialist skills are not 
available and need to be acquired (e.g., underwriters, actuaries, loss adjustors, fund managers). 
The framework for insurance supervision has been developed but material deficiencies in terms 
of capacity for supervision remain.  
 
22.  Capital  Market.  Cambodia  has  no  bond  and  securities  markets.  The  Law  on 
Government Securities was enacted in January 2007 and the non-government securities law 
was subsequently adopted by the National Assembly in September 2007. The most recent 
short-term government securities were issued in 2005. The placement of government securities 
is jointly organized by NBC and the commercial banks. The Government has established a 
capital market unit in MEF and in April 2007 signed a memorandum of understanding with the 
stock exchange of the Republic of Korea for $1.8 million worth of technical assistance to help 
with the initial training and preparation for the establishment of a securities market in the near 
future. 
 
23.  Accounting and Auditing Infrastructure. The continuing growth of the commercial 
sector is creating significant challenges to improve the quality of accounting and auditing, and to 
produce sufficient numbers of qualified accountants. Cambodia has established a legal and 
regulatory framework for accounting and auditing, but inconsistencies between the various laws 
and regulations remain with some aspects difficult to interpret and weakness in the overall 
framework. Fifteen Cambodian accounting standards and 10 Cambodian accounting standards 
have been introduced but are not consistent with international standards. A standards advisory 
body and a local institute of accountants have been established to oversee this. 
 
24.  The accounting profession is in its infancy. The 11 public accounting and auditing firms 
employ 30 resident qualified accountants, 10 of whom are locally qualified. Currently more than 
12,000 companies are registered and the rate of registration is growing. The public accounting 
firms have few, if any, local clients. To date more than 1,000 students have enrolled in the local 
accounting qualification course, but approximately 40% of those have either dropped out or 
been dismissed. Seventeen students, including those not employed in public accounting, are 
qualified  certified  public  accountants  but  the  vast  majority  of  students  are  experiencing 
difficulties completing the early stages of the course.  
 
25.  Legal  Infrastructure.  An  enabling  legal  framework  for  financial  and  commercial 
transactions could be achieved by continuing support for Cambodia’s process of law reform, 
including  the  adoption and  implementation  of core  financial  and commercial  laws  that  are 
harmonized  and  aligned  with  the  legal  system.  The  law  reform  process  in  financial  and 
commercial areas aims to create an enabling environment for the financial sector and for

economic growth in general. The Government has taken important steps to prepare, adopt, and 
implement  certain  major  laws.  The  second  stage  of  development  is  for  additions  and 
refinements to be made to the legal framework. 
 
26.  The  process  for  enacting  a  new  law  is  subject  to  several  documented  steps.  In  a 
common situation, where an international legal expert has provided assistance and produced a 
draft document in English, the translation into Khmer would take a minimum of 2–3 weeks. Then 
the  process  of  internal  debate  and  consultation  is  held  within  the  ministry  responsible  for 
introducing the new law. Following these steps, the procedures pertaining to the passage of the 
law through the Council of Ministers and National Assembly are usually lengthy: approval by the 
Council of Ministers usually take at least 6 months (but usually longer), and the process for 
submission to the National Assembly and the approval process within the assembly itself is 
estimated to take approximately 1 year. As a consequence, delay is always a risk at any given 
stage of the legislative process. 
 
27.  The current court process for the enforcement of collateral is seen as lengthy, uncertain, 
and subject to delays, including the process for appeal. The current situation calls for an urgent 
strengthening of Cambodia’s dispute resolution system as it is a critical element of the emerging 
financial and commercial legal framework. The introduction of commercial arbitration under the 
new Law on Commercial Arbitration will be a key mechanism to consistently enforce contracts 
and  fairly  resolve  commercial  disputes.  A  new  commercial  court  sponsored  by  the  United 
Nations and other bilateral development partners, still in the planning stages, has the potential 
for improving transparency and finality under clearly set court procedures.

CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE PAYMENT SYSTEM 
 
1.  The Payments Policy Unit (PPU) will play an important role in the evolution of the 
payment system in Cambodia. The staff are young, with little experience, and need extensive 
training and opportunities to gain operational experience to improve their effectiveness. They 
will need to establish relationships with commercial banks and other authorized users. 
 
2.  The  current  clearing  and  settlement  system  for  checks  is  effective  but  needs 
improvements.  Improvement  could  be  made  by  having  the  clearing  performed  during 
nonbanking business hours at around 6:00 p.m. each business day. Dishonored checks would 
then be presented the next business day at 9:00 a.m., with settlement shortly thereafter and 
completed no later than 10:00 a.m. This approach would allow banks to provide funds to the 
beneficiary of a check payment the next business day by 10:00 a.m., 18–20 hours sooner than 
currently offered. If the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) does not wish to provide the clearing 
at this proposed time, then the banks could provide the clearing at some designated location 
and the return processing could be accommodated by 9:00 a.m. at NBC the next business day. 
To determine if this is a feasible proposal and the impact on the banking community and their 
customer base, PPU should develop a policy paper outlining the many issues of concern; how 
they might be resolved; and the impact on NBC, the banks, and bank customers.  
 
3.  If check volumes reach the point where some banks see benefits to automating their 
back  office  processes,  then  the  standardization  of  checks  used  in  Cambodia  could  be 
considered, along with the development of bank identification numbers. Section A (paras. 6–9) 
indicates the steps involved in making these changes. 
 
4.  In many countries, the evolution of the noncash retail payment system is left to the 
private  sector  to  manage  and  implement  with  the  central  bank  providing  only  settlement 
services. If the private sector in Cambodia prefers that NBC perform this responsibility, then 
perhaps NBC should immediately begin developing an automatic clearinghouse for electronic 
payments following the steps outlined for the development of a real time gross settlement 
(RTGS) system. Otherwise, NBC’s resources should be directed to the development of an 
effective means of handling large value transactions on a gross basis, either through the use of 
SWIFT1 as a communications system or through a fully electronic RTGS system. 
 
5.  Development of either a retail or wholesale payment system will take some time. Section 
B (paras. 10–32) outlines steps needed to identify a vendor that could provide an RTGS system. 
The process would take from 24 to 36 months. A similar process would be required to develop 
an  automatic  clearinghouse  and  may  take  a  similar  amount  of  time,  although  it  could  be 
accomplished with a separate team and move forward concurrently if NBC is unwilling to leave 
this to the private sector.

B.   Implementing an RTGS System 
 
10.  Installing an RTGS system in the most effective way and at the least cost requires 
several steps. Probably the most important is developing a user requirements document. This 
document should describe the detailed needs that all expect the system to meet. It should be 
developed with input from all affected areas of NBC and all the banks to be connected to the 
system to ensure the various reports and other needs are achieved. PPU could be given this 
responsibility, perhaps with some outside help from a consultant. 
 
11.  The user requirements document should be divided into a number of sections, and cover 
in detail: data entry, data validation, data communications, data processing, data storage, data 
presentation,  security,  reliability,  and  planning  for  the  event  of  failure  of  some  system 
component, or of the system in its entirety.  
 
12.  A vision of what the system would perform and how it would operate, i.e., the system 
design, is formulated from the user requirements. The design of an RTGS system should be 
guided by the Core Principles for Systemically Important Payment Systems developed by the 
Bank  for  International  Settlements.  In  addition,  the  design  should  be  prepared  to  mitigate 
payment system risk, including credit, legal, liquidity, operational, systemic, and other risks 
normally covered by payment systems.  
 
13.  The user requirements document provides a broad overview of what is envisioned for 
the system and its objectives, including the risks that need to be mitigated. Development of a 
user requirements document should have the support of all the NBC user departments and 
move forward at a steady pace. Realistically, it would take 4–8 months to effectively develop 
and review. Banks should have an understanding of what is happening and the requirements 
should be shared with them for their views. 
 
1.  Data Entry 
 
14.  The data entry portion of the document outlines the information needed to process the 
payment instruction and to ensure that the receiving bank has sufficient information to post the 
amounts to the account of the intended beneficiary. The receiving bank could accomplish this 
task either manually or electronically. Adopting the SWIFT format may be a good place to start 
and then ensure that these message formats meet the needs of the program participants. The 
format may need to be customized for local issues that are unique to Cambodia. 
 
15.  In  addition,  the  SWIFT  format  would  identify  the  various  data  elements  needed  to 
consummate the transaction. Setting up appropriate codes, such as uniform bank identification 
codes, customer account codes, and proper formatting principles, is important. In addition, 
access to the terminal to be used for entering the basic data requires some form of control 
processes to prevent unauthorized transactions. 
 
2.  Data Validation 
 
16.  Data must be entered accurately. Once the transaction is released for processing and 
forwarded to the receiving bank, little or no time is available to catch an invalid transaction or a 
transaction  with  erroneous  information.  The  sending  bank  is  totally  liable  and  their  data 
validation procedures should therefore be strong to prevent any mishap. One way of ensuring 
this process is to divide duties so that the person who enters the original data does not validate 
it. The person validating should reenter selected and important data elements, such as the

receiving  bank  identification,  amount,  and  beneficiary  information.  The  computer  can  then 
validate the correctness of the information. If accurate, it can be queued for release, or if not 
accurate, returned to the data entry person for correction. One person to enter and correct the 
data,  the  second  person  to  validate  and  release  the  transaction,  is  the  minimum  staffing 
required to enter and send transaction data at any point of entrance. The system should allow 
for more people to be involved and to divide their duties, but prevent the person that enters data 
from validating and releasing the data. 
 
3.  Data Communication or Transmission 
 
17.  Once the data is entered and validated, it is ready for release into the system. Once 
released, no human intervention should occur until it reaches the receiving bank unless an 
unanticipated major problem occurs. The transaction should flow through the system until it is 
delivered to the receiving bank, and possibly even to the beneficiary’s account, depending on 
the capabilities available at the receiving bank in its delivery of information to customers. Some 
receiving banks may elect to advise a customer electronically of the receipt of incoming funds. 
 
18.  During the transmission process, the system should provide a high degree of reliability to 
ensure that the data is transmitted accurately and the error correction procedures operated 
correctly in case part of the information is lost during transmission. This is a vendor issue, but 
must be understood by the technical staff who will be part of the evaluation team. The vendor 
should identify the approaches taken to ensure integrity of the data being sent and received, 
and how that integrity is validated. Encryption is very important to ensure that data retains its 
integrity,  and  is  not  viewed  by  unauthorized  persons  during  the  transmission  process. 
Authentication processes help to automatically validate the identity of the sending bank for the 
receiving banks. 
 
4.  Data Processing 
   
19.  Processing of the data received basically involves debiting the current account of the 
sending bank at NBC and simultaneously crediting the current account of the receiving bank at 
NBC. Most of the time, this will be very simple. However, before the transaction is posted, the 
system must confirm the information in the transaction is accurate and valid for use at NBC. 
Further, some form of authentication is required to confirm that the information came from the 
sending bank that wants its account debited.  
 
20.  Once NBC is satisfied (based on the criteria programmed into the system), posting may 
occur. If funds in the sending bank's settlement account at NBC are not sufficient, then a 
number of options arise. One approach is to outright reject the transaction and return it as 
unprocessed to the sending bank. Another option is to queue the transaction for up to 30 
minutes or until the sending bank receives sufficient funds from another source. Still another 
possibility  is  to  have  a  predetermined  line  of  credit  with  sufficient  collateral  to  allow  the 
transaction to move forward. Liquidity management would become easier if NBC decided to 
centralize  all  operations  and  bank  account  balances  at  head  office  and  not  have  any 
commercial  bank  account  balances  in  the  NBC  branch  offices.  These  approaches  are 
reasonable and simple to implement. Other more sophisticated approaches are costly. The user 
requirements document must indicate the various approaches that NBC is willing to support to 
help with liquidity management at the sending bank. At the end of the day, any unprocessed 
transactions would be returned to the sending bank for resubmission at a later time.

  5.  Data Storage 
 
21.  All transactions are stored in the system for some reasonable time to provide for online 
retrieval  in  the  case  of  disputes  or  other  information  and  historical  statistical  needs.  The 
database should have robust retrieval features and storage sufficient to enable the system to 
retain at least 6 months of transactions. This would also allow for retrieval of information for 
analysis in determine activities in the payment system on a national basis. Storing data on an 
encrypted  basis  helps  retain  the  integrity  of  the  data  over  longer  periods,  and  prevents 
unauthorized users from understanding the data should they suddenly find that they have 
access to such files. 
 
6.  Data Presentation 
 
22.  Presenting the transaction to the receiving bank is in some ways the most important part 
of the process. Probably this will be in the SWIFT message format, which is widely used 
internationally for large value transactions. Also, reports at NBC need to be identified for posting 
to settlement accounts at the end of the day, and for audit trail purposes. Further, end of month 
reports will need to be identified, along with the data that is to be captured, analyzed, and saved 
for future use. Needs of the various users should be defined as well as how the information 
technology infrastructure will be used to forward the various reports to the users. Interfacing to 
stand-alone  systems  for  other  analytical  purposes  will  require  definition  for  forwarding  the 
appropriate data.  
 
7.  Security and Access Control 
 
23.  Controlling who is to use the system is vitally important. Most systems are able to deny 
access to unauthorized users through the use of user identification (user-id) and a personal 
identification number (PIN). The system can also dictate the frequency at which the PIN should 
be changed for each user, and ensure that the user actually changes the PIN. However, 
management at all locations (NBC and the authorized users) must ensure that the user-id is 
current and that the user-ids of employees who no longer have a need to access the system are 
removed on a timely basis. 
 
8.  Reliability 
   
24.  All  critical  components  of  the  system  must  work  throughout  the  processing  day. 
Frequently,  some  redundancy  of  equipment  is  required  to  ensure  high  reliability  for  each 
operating day. Also, spare parts for some components may be needed to ensure users have 
access and the system is able to provide service under a wide variety of situations. This 
includes backup electrical power, filters to ensure no electrical power interruption for equipment 
and air conditioning units, alternate data communication lines (e.g., dial backup is a possibility) 
and terminals, and appropriate staff resources. In some cases when an authorized user’s 
terminal  is  malfunctioning,  NBC  should  have  one  or  two  standby  terminals  that  can  be 
configured so that a user may come to NBC and enter their daily transactions directly. 
 
9.  Business Continuity 
   
25.  This area concerns the service that will be provided should a situation arise where the 
main NBC site is closed because of some catastrophic event that was not foreseen or is 
uncontrollable. While these events are of low probability, they do occur from time to time. 
Perhaps in Cambodia, fire, severe water damage, or an extensive loss of electrical power might

Appendix 5  63 
be the most likely events that could disrupt an RTGS system. A remote backup site, generally a 
good distance from the primary site, is the usual solution to overcome this risk. For operational 
purposes, some staff may have to be relocated, while in other situations useful work can be 
accomplished  at  the  remote  site  to  support  the  need  for  off-site  operating  staff.  Since 
transactions are recorded on a real-time basis at the backup site throughout the operating day, 
putting a backup site into operation needs to be rapid and the communication infrastructure is 
critical. 
 
26.  An effective backup site requires appropriately trained staff available at, or able to go 
quickly, under any conditions, to the backup site; and sufficient data communication capability 
so that the system can operate from the backup site with the same degree of effectiveness and 
integrity as from the primary site. 
 
10.  Tender Development  
 
27.  Once the user requirements are documented and all the identified issues addressed and 
documented, then an RFP can be developed and forwarded to possible vendors. Much basic 
information is required for normal acquisition processes. This information will be part of NBC’s 
normal procurement process (and the requirements of any donor or lending organization that 
may be involved in helping NBC install such a system). It should also include the criteria to be 
used to evaluate the responses and the weight applied to each criterion. Vendors should be 
given from 30 to 60 days to respond to an RFP with the longer times given for the more complex 
approaches. An RTGS system is considered complex, and generally the more time given for 
developing the response the better the reply. Once the tender is released, an evaluation team 
needs to be organized and understand the criteria for the selection process. Their availability 
will become critical once the responses are received, usually on the last possible day for receipt, 
to perform the evaluation to help with vendor selection (paras. 28–30). Members of the team 
should  represent  various  NBC  departments  (information  technology,  accounting,  banking 
operations, and PPU at a minimum), and perhaps one or two knowledgeable commercial bank 
representatives with experience in payment systems and bank operations. 
 
11.  Vendor Selection 
 
28.  After the responses are received, the evaluation team needs to review each response 
and analyze the various criteria. Each member of the team should evaluate each response 
independently and come to a conclusion for each responder based on the criteria. Each criterion 
will have a separate weight for rating agreed to in advance. Cost should carry a low weight, 
while functionality and the ability to meet the user requirements should have one of the highest 
ratings. Once this process is complete, one person, perhaps a consultant, will take all the 
evaluations and analyze them to identify the three best vendor solutions requiring detailed 
analysis (i.e., a short list). The analyst should review the reasons used to justify why the three 
vendors were short-listed for further review.  
 
29.  These vendors should be invited to make a formal presentation, or visited, to better 
understand their approach (one method should be selected, not a mixture of the two.) The entire 
evaluation process needs to be objective, and must be performed in an ethical manner with no 
edge given to one vendor over another. Once the vendors have been reviewed, the evaluation 
team will provide a recommendation that must be supported by a written evaluation as to why 
the selected vendor is the best of the three. The recommendation will be forwarded to NBC 
management for approval and for subsequent contract negotiation prior to moving forward with 
other elements of the project.

64  Appendix 5 
30.  This process, from the development of user requirements through the preparation of the 
RFP, to the vendor selection, may take from 12 to more than 18 months depending on the 
abilities of PPU, other NBC departments, consultants, and others involved in the process. 
 
12.  Management Approval 
 
31.  This process may take a short or long time, depending upon the interest of management 
and  the  detail  of  the  presentation.  Management  should  either  accept  or  reject  the 
recommendation. Management should not be involved in the selection process, nor have direct 
contact with any of the vendors being considered for the project during the selection process. 
 
13.  Contract Negotiations and Design Evaluation 
 
32.  Once management approval is given to move forward with the selected vendor, time 
must be taken to ensure that all parties understand the intent of the other. The vendor has a 
product to sell and the acquirer wants to assure that the product will meet their needs to the 
fullest extent possible. At this time the acquirer has the most leverage over the vendor to ensure 
that all elements of the project will be met. In a later mode, the technicians will need to ensure 
that the system design will meet the user requirements and understand how the vendor will 
achieve those results. During both situations, an opportunity should be provided for both parties 
to cede from the project and for NBC to possibly select another vendor. For this reason, 
potentially unsuccessful vendors should not be notified of the situation until a contract has been 
agreed to by all parties.

FSP II IMPLEMENTATION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Outputs 
1.  The primary purpose of the technical assistance (TA) is to help the Government improve 
the capacity of the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC), which is the Executing Agency, and the 
Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) and Ministry of Commerce (MOC), which are the 
implementing agencies, to design and implement key reforms in the financial sector as well as 
to provide the Government with timely policy advice on a demand basis. The objective of the 
advisory TA is to provide assistance to the Government to find practical solutions to address 
these issues, as well as to deepen the Government’s reform agenda in the financial sector. The 
reforms, to be implemented under subprogram 1 of the Second Financial Sector Program 
Cluster (FSP II), and reform triggers for subprogram 2 are expected to promote confidence, 
growth in outreach, good governance, efficiency, and resilience. Implementation of the reforms 
will  require  technical  inputs  and  targeted  on-the-job  support  to  equip  the  key  government 
agencies (NBC, MEF, MOC) with the required knowledge and skills to ensure that the results of 
the reforms will be sustained even after FSP II. 
 
2.  The components of the TA are as follows: 
 
(i)  Improve  the  payments,  clearance,  and  settlement  system.  On-the-job 
guidance and training of Payments Policy Unit staff to assist them in formulating 
appropriate policy papers for management consideration; building awareness 
within  and  outside  of  NBC;  and  undertaking  constructive  dialogue  with  the 
banking subsector in implementing the road map for modernizing the payments, 
clearance, and settlement system. 
(ii)  Support  international  initiatives  on  anti-money  laundering  and  counter 
financing of terrorism (AML and CFT). Support the development and adoption 
of the AML subdecree, formulate procedures and compliance programs for the 
Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU), prepare reporting forms, assist in setting up the 
FIU, and provide training for FIU staff and compliance officers of the reporting 
financial institutions. 
(iii)  Provide management and technical support for the information technology 
project to computerize key NBC operations. Prepare bidding documents; help 
with the bidding process; evaluate bids; provide assistance during negotiation 
and finalization of the contracts; and oversee installation of the hardware and 
software systems, data conversion, initial testing, training, and troubleshooting. 
(iv)  Strengthen bank supervision. Strengthen the on-site supervision capacity of 
the bank regulator in tandem with AML and CFT implementation, and develop 
remedial measures to address emerging problems with high-risk banks. 
(v)  Strengthen supervision of microfinance institutions (MFIs) with appropriate 
regulations. Improve the prudential regulations for MFIs and strengthen the 
capacity of the regulator within NBC to implement those regulations. 
(vi)  Establish  the  national  arbitration  center.  Assist  MOC  in  finalizing  the 
implementing subdecree, setting up the national arbitration center by developing 
appropriate  rules  and  procedures,  providing  guidance  on  the  procedure  for 
selecting  credible  members,  undertaking  public  awareness  workshops,  and 
training members and potential customers of the center. 
(vii)  Strengthen the training capability of the Center for Banking Studies. Assist 
the  center  in  reviewing  its  curriculum  with  the  objective  of  updating  training 
materials and expanding the scope of its curriculum to include aspects of MFI
